div3.head:
[Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.]
thing in Alabama
div3.p:
No State in the Confederacy has more nobly carried herself in the present great struggle than Alabama — the land of flowers.
It almost makes a true Southerner shout for joy to hear the planters speak of what they are willing to do and to suffer for the maintenance of their rights and independence — In many portions of the State if one were to plant at ordinary crop of cotton he would not raise a pound, for public sentiment is so intensified that his fences would be thrown down and be treated as a traitor.
Those who stay at home, in many sections are signing instruments of writing pledging themselves to divide with the families of volunteers as long as they have a perk of meal or a pound of meat.
Gov. Shorter's call for more men is meeting with a noble response, while almost every shop in the State is making pikes, knives, and other weapons with which to make the invader "bite the dust." No true man can pass through this State and mingle with the people without having his heart swell with admiration for the women, the patriotic, enthusiastic women of Alabama--in one county five hundred true-hearted wives and daughters have gone into the fields, planting corn and doing all the out-door work, in order that their husbands, brothers, and sons may go to the war. Within nine fourths a lady in this city, (by the-way, she care from Old Virginia,) has been at church every day, (except eight days, when it was impossible to be there,) sewing for the soldiers.
The hearts and hands of our women are worth to us an army of one hundred thousand men. Gov. Shorter is acting nobly his part.
He is an earnest-hearted Christian statesman.

div3.head:
[Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch]
a teaching incident.
div3.p: In an example to those of our fellow-citizens who have grown dependent to a large extent, I will relate an incident which came within my own observation and hearing, deeply impressing me, with several others who were present.

Between the hours of 12 A. M and 1 P. M., I was sitting in the gentlemen's reception room at the Atlantic Hotel, waiting partially the round of the gong, the most welcome music to the ear of the epicure.--On the opposite side of the room from myself was seated a young man, dressed in the apparel of an artillery officer — apparently absorbed in the contents of the Dispatch Suddenly he let it drop from before his eyes, and in an excited but determined to be remarked, "And it is left for me to average his blood, and I'll do it, or lay my heart upon the altar a sacrifice to the cause" Feeling anxious to know the cause of such an assertion, I interrogated him-when he informed me that he had just read the aid intelligence that his brother P. G. Embark, was mortally wounded in the fight near Winchester.
Every expression of the face — every move of the countenance, left no doubt but that the firm dissolve was then and there made to make good his declaration.

We should bear up with a fortitude and a will more deterred and; as gloom and my fortune closes around 8.
It is not the part of brave men and good citizens to falter, when the Sense of our success begins to waver..--On the contrary, it should be the maid: touch-stone to renewed energy — to a more unconquerable determination to be fee. We want no indecisive, lukewarm spirits, in these times; but brave men, who believing our cause just, go forth exulting in the confident belief that our efforts will ultimately be crowned with victory, &c. div3.head: Gen. J. Bankhead Magruder.
div3.p: A Virginia correspondent of the New Orleans Deltas, describing the proceedings of a dinner given to Gen. Magruder and Gen. McLaws, on the Peninsula, by the line officers of the 5th Louisiana regiment, gives a sketch of Gen. Magruder's remarks in reply to a toast to the "Hero of Bethel."

Though Gen. Magruder does not pretend to be a speaker, yet there is a native manhood about him, a fiery enthusiasm in his delivery, which commands attention and admiration.
He is every inch a soldier, a real General, and wherever the country wants a strong arm and a giant will, it can rely on him. He said he was extremely gratified to meet his brother officers of the 5th Louisiana regiment, and acknowledged in handsome terms the compliment designed for him — that he was happy to have an opportunity to meet them upon such a festive occasion, as his intercourse with the regiment, from the incessant demands the defence of the Peninsula imposed upon him up to this time, had produced, he feared, impressions unfavorable to his possible;that he had perhaps been curt, abrupt and wanting in the courtesies which he would have liked to have extended to one and all of them, but that he was so absorbed with the proper preparations of the Peninsula for resisting the enemy, that he had absolutely ignored all pretensions to politicoes, and he desired now to make the serenade to any one who felt as grieved.
I would not have "heard his enemy say so," for in my intercourse with him I always found him a most polished and elegant gentleman and he is generally remarkable for his affable manners.
He said that now the labor was done, that the people of the Peninsula might sleep in peace, for he did not believe the Yankees could successfully force him from his position, it mattered not where or when they came.
Alluding to the house in which the dinner was given, he was reminded, has said, of the first time he entered it; its owner had given it up as lost; and left upon the mantel-piece some marine curiosity he valued highly, with a note to the first generous Yankee who entered it to retrain from destroying his property.
Everybody was fleeing from the Peninsula — the first gun had hardly been counted at Yorktown.
By the real, devotion and ready obedience of the volunteers in marches, countermarch, building of fortifications and defences, it had been thus preferred from the pollution of the Yankee invader, and instead of their having Colonel Young's house and form, we were now enjoying the pleasures of a festive scene that ignored the proximity of a formidable enemy such was the fruit of the policy he had inaugurated from the first and it was the secret of the matching, countermarching, bivouacking and embankment making which had doubtless made the volunteers think their duties hard under him. * * * * He wished that the country might know and appreciate the alacrity and devotion with which the volunteers under him had been red and discharged their duties, and had won bloodies a victoriously the precautions which kept the enemy from attacking; and when they did would certainly insure successes arms.
He spoke of Bethel with fabulous modesty, and proved to my mind that the battle was almost was by his masterly strategy.
None can deny that it effect on the enemy was deadening; on us, as inflicting them at of series of brilliant victories in maintenance of the nationality we claim before the nations of the earth, of incalculable importance.
He minded in feeling arms and so did Colonel , to the memory of gallant Charles Deux.
He said: He won upon my love, as he did on us who know him. He fell on the field of glory, and sealed his devotion to his country with his heart's best blood.
It was from this hours he asked my permission to allow some of his young friends to go down and feel the enemy, and I assented, provided he would not allow less than a hundred to go; but I have dreamed that: he considered himself the youngest of the young, and that he would lead them." He pronounced a teaching on upon his chivalric and military qualities, and cropped a soldier's ear to Louisiana's offering on the altar of liberty.
He mentioned a circumstance of historical interest in connection with his death.
He said the battalion under Col. Righter, with his reprobation, had sent a challenge to the Yankees to select five hundred of their side, regulars or volunteers, and they would test with them on any ground whether they had to won Draux's blood on worthily; "and," raid the General, determined that if it were accepted.
I would join them with my musket and knapsack --for I make a capital private — and share their fate.
The challenge, however, was never accepted; but in all the marches and a tempts I have made to engage the enemy, I placed this battalion purposely in a position where they might avenge the death of Dreux, if an opportunity occurred."

div3.head: An interesting Religious meeting
div3.p:
"A large and enthusiastic mass meeting was held with the Presbyterian Church of this city, Sunday evening, in behalf of army colportage.
Rev. Dr. Petric introduced the services by some pertinent remarks, and called Gov. Shorter to preside.
On taking the chair, the Governor delivered a speech of great eloquence and power.
His remarks produced a deep impression and enlisted much interest in the work which he represents, as one of the most important now before the people of the South.
He was followed by Rev. A. B. Dickinson, of Richmond, Va, who gave many interesting facts in reference to the practical working of the system with which he has been identified from the beginning of the way. Rev. Manly, D, D, delivered an address, after which a collection was made accounting to three hundred and fifty dollars--Montgomery (Ala) Advertiser.

In an affray in Lynchburg, last Friday, David Pettigrew was shot and badly wounded by Hillary Padgett.
The latter has been arrested.
